label: ePO System Apply Tag Example
info:
This sample invokes and displays the results of a `system.applyTag` remote
command via the ePO DXL service. The results of the apply command are displayed
on the Node-RED `debug` tab.

### Prerequisites

* The samples configuration step has been completed (see the
  [DXL Configuration Sample](https://github.com/opendxl/node-red-contrib-dxl/wiki/Client-Configuration)).
* A ePO DXL service is running and available on the DXL fabric. If version 5.0
  or later of the DXL ePO extensions are installed on your ePO server, an ePO
  DXL service should already be running on the fabric. If you are using an
  earlier version of the DXL ePO extensions, you can use the
  [ePO DXL Python Service](https://github.com/opendxl/opendxl-epo-service-python).
* The DXL client associated with the `Apply system tag in ePO` node is
  authorized to invoke the ePO DXL service, and the user that is connecting to
  the ePO server (within the ePO DXL service) has permission to execute the
  `system.applyTag` remote command (see
  [Client Authorization](https://opendxl.github.io/opendxl-epo-client-python/pydoc/authorization.html)).

### Setup

* If more than one ePO service is available on the DXL fabric that the DXL
  client is connecting to, edit the `Apply system tag in ePO` node and set the
  `ePO Id` property to that of the ePO service through which the remote command
  should be performed. By default, the `ePO Id` property is empty, in which case
  the client attempts to dynamically determine the id of the ePO service to
  communicate with.
* Edit the `Specify systems to tag` node and modify the `Payload` property with
  the name(s) of the system(s) to apply the tag to. System names should be
  separated by commas. For example:

  ```
  system1,system2
  ```

* Edit the `Apply system tag in ePO` node and modify the `Tag name` property
  with the name of the tag to apply. For example:

  ```
  mytag1
  ```
  
* To deploy the flow, press the `Deploy` button in the upper-right corner of the
  screen. If Node-RED is able to properly connect to the DXL fabric, a green dot
  with the word `connected` should appear under the `Apply system tag in ePO`
  node.

### Running

To exercise the flow, double-click the button on the left side of the
`Specify systems to tag` node.

### Output

The number of systems that the tag was applied to should appear in the Node-RED
`debug` tab. For example:

```
2
```

### Details

The flow exercises the nodes below.

#### Specify systems to tag

This is an `inject` input node which starts the flow. This node injects a new
message with a `payload` property which specifies the name(s) of the system(s)
to apply the tag to.

#### Set names request parameter

This is a `change` node which copies the value from the `payload` property on
the message to the `names` property. The `Apply system tag in ePO` node uses the `names` property when
constructing the parameters for the `system.applyTag` remote command. 

#### Apply system tag in ePO

This is an `epo system apply tag` node. This node connects to the DXL fabric and
sends a DXL `Request` message to the ePO service. The message specifies the
target remote command as `system.applyTag`.

The request message also includes the `msg.names` property set by the
`Set names request parameter` node and the `tagName` set in the
`Tag name` property.
 
The `Return` property is set to "a parsed JSON object" and the `Format` property
is set to "JSON" to indicate that the payload for the response should be
added to the output message as a JavaScript object decoded from JSON.

#### Output result

This is a `debug` output node. This node outputs the `payload` set on
the message by the `Apply system tag in ePO` node. The output should include
the response received from the DXL fabric for the `system.applyTag` command.
